Key Arguments: The proposed legislation conflicts with Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which guarantees freedom of opinion and expression.
The definitions of 'harm' in the Bill are vague and subjective, potentially encompassing a wide range of expressions.
The Bill could be used to suppress dissenting opinions on topics like COVID-19 and climate change.
The legislation would give the government excessive power over truth, which is historically dangerous.
The Bill would have a chilling effect on free expression and the exchange of ideas.
The suppression of free speech is more harmful than the abuse of free speech.
Notable Quotes: The 'Communications Legislation Amendment (Combatting Misinformation and Disinformation) Bill 2023' is in clear conflict with the Declaration.
The Government of the day is setting itself up, via ACMA, as the fountain of all truth.
If this Bill were to become law it would have a disastrously chilling effect on free expression and the exchange of ideas.
As George Orwell said, 'If liberty means anything at all, it means the right to tell people what they do not want to hear.'
